facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 292 and 312 of 1950 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 292 and 312 of 1950. Appeals from the Judgment and Order of the High Court of Judicature at Hyderaba

facts.text: Appeals from judgment and order of High Court of Judicature at Hyderabad in Cases Nos. 180-181 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the Judgment and Order of the High Court of Judicature at Hyderabad  Ansari, Qamar Hasan and Manohar Pershad JJ.  in Cases Nos. 180-181 of 1954

facts.text: Dewan Bahadur Ramgopal Mills Company Ltd. registered on 14th February 1920 at Hyderabad.

anchor.surface_text: The Mills Company was registered on the 14th February, 1920, at Hyderabad in the then territories of His Exalted Highness the Nizam.

facts.text: Appellants registered as a private limited company at Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were registered as a private limited companypany at Bombay on agreement was entered into between the Mills Company.

facts.text: Agency agreement entered into between Mills Company and appellants appointing appellants as agents for 30 years.

anchor.surface_text: on agreement was entered into between the Mills Company. and the appellants appointing the appellants its Agents for a period of 30 years on certain terms and companyditions therein recorded.

facts.text: Appellants received remuneration under agency agreement for Fasli years 1351 and 1352.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants throughout worked only as the Agents of the Mills Company and for the Fasli years 1351 and 1352 they received their remuneration under the terms of the Agency agreement.

facts.text: Notice issued under section 13 of Hyderabad Excess Profits Tax Regulation by Excess Profits Tax Officer to appellants.

anchor.surface_text: A numberice was issued under section 13 of the Hyderabad Excess Profits Tax Regulation by the Excess Profits Tax Officer calling upon the appellants to pay the, amount of tax appertaining to these chargeable account- , ing periods.

facts.text: Appellants contended remuneration not taxable as not income, profits or gains from business.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants submitted their accounts and companytended that the remuneration received by them from the Mills Company was number taxable on the ground that it is was number income, profits or gains from business

facts.text: Excess Profits Tax Officer assessed appellants' income for Fasli 1351 at Rs. 8,957 and for 1352 at Rs. 83,768 on 24th April 1944.

anchor.surface_text: on the 24th April, 1944, the Excess Profits Tax Officer made an order assessing the income of the appellants for the accounting periods 1351 and 1352 Fasli at Rs. 8,957 and Rs. 83,768 respectively and assessed the tax accordingly.

facts.text: Appeal by appellants to Deputy Commissioner of Excess Profits Tax disallowed.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal was taken by the appellants to the Deputy Commissioner of Excess Profits Tax who disallowed the same.

facts.text: Application under section 48(2) for statement of case rejected by Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: An application made by the appellants under section 48 2  for statement of the case to the High Court was rejected by the Commissioner

facts.text: High Court directed Commissioner to state case on petition under section 48(3).

anchor.surface_text: and the appellants filed a petition to the High Court under section 48 3  to companypel the Commissioner to state the case to the High Court. An order was made by the High,Court on this petition directing the Commissioner to state the case

facts.text: Commissioner submitted statement of case on 26th February 1946.

anchor.surface_text: and the statement of the case was submitted by the Commis- sioner on the 26th February, 1946.

facts.text: Four specific questions referred to High Court by Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: Four questions were referred by the Commissioner to the High Courts as under- Whether the Petitioner Company is a partnership firm or a registered firm ? Whether under the terms of the agreement the petitioner is an employee of the Mills Company or is carrying on business ?

facts.text: Full Bench of High Court decided questions 2 and 3 against appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The Full Bench of the High Court delivered their judgment the majority deciding the questions  2  and  3  which were the only questions companysidered determinative of the reference against the appellants.

facts.text: Appeals to Judicial Committee, but transferred to Supreme Court after merger of Hyderabad.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants appealed to the Judicial Committee. But before the Judicial Committee heard the appeals there was a merger of the territories of Hyderabad with India.

facts.text: Appeals transferred to Supreme Court at Delhi on 12th December 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals finally came for hearing before the Supreme Court Bench at Hyderabad on the 12th December, 1950, when an order was passed transferring the appeals to this Court at Delhi.

facts.text: Appellants' objects include acting as agents and carrying on agency business.

anchor.surface_text: the objects for which they were incorporated were the following To act as agents for Governments or Authorities or for any bankers, manufacturers, merchants, shippers, Joint Stock Companies and others and carry on all kinds of agency business.

facts.text: Under Article 115 of Mills Company's Articles, appellants appointed agents per agreement.

anchor.surface_text: Under Article 115 of the Articles of Association of the Mills Company the appellants and their assigns were appointed the agents of the Company upon the terms, -provisions and companyditions set out in the Agreement

facts.text: Agency agreement remuneration: 2-1/2% commission on sale proceeds.

anchor.surface_text: The remuneration of the appellants as such Agents was to be a companymission of per cent on the amount of sale proceeds of all yarn cloth and other produce of the Company  including companyton grown  which companymission

arguments.claim: Company carrying professional services is trade not profession per William Esplen case
Exclusion for personal qualifications does not apply to companies or firms

anchor.surface_text: Whether the appellants are a partnership firm or a registered company the principle of exclusion of the income from the category of business income by reason of its depending wholly or mainly on the personal qualifications of the assessee would not apply

holdings.text: The principle of exclusion of income from business by reason of depending wholly or mainly on personal qualifications does not apply to partnership firms or registered companies

anchor.surface_text: Whether the appellants are a partnership firm or a registered company the principle of exclusion of the income from the category of business income by reason of its depending wholly or mainly on the personal qualifications of the assessee would not apply because the income could not be said to be income from profession and neither a partnership firm nor a registered company as such could be said to be possessed of any personal qualifications in the matter of the acquisition of that income.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Firms and companies lack personal qualifications; income not from excluded profession

holdings.text: The appellants were agents of the Company and not merely servants remunerated by wages or salary

anchor.surface_text: All these circumstances together with the power of sub- delegation reserved under Article 118 in our opinion go to establish that the appellants were the agents of the Company and not merely the servants of the Company remunerated by wages or salary.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Discretion in method of work, commission remuneration, assignability of rights, fixed tenure, sub-delegation powers; distinguished from servant control test citing Powell and Halsbury

holdings.text: The activities of the appellants as agents constituted carrying on business

anchor.surface_text: All these factors taken, into consideration alongwith the fixity of tenure, the nature of remuneration and the assignability of their rights, are sufficient to enable us to come to the conclusion that the activities of the appellants as the agents of the Company constituted a business

holdings.reasoning_summary: Nature and scope of management activities, continuity, objects clause permit agency business, even restricted to one company; fixity of tenure, remuneration, assignability

holdings.text: The remuneration received by the appellants was income, profits or gains from business

anchor.surface_text: the remuneration which the appellants received from the Company under the terms of the Agency Agreement was income, profits or gain from business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from finding of agency relationship involving carrying on business activities

holdings.text: The activities of the appellants come within the inclusive definition of business under section 2 clause 4
holdings.reasoning_summary: Broad interpretation includes rendering services beyond strict trade/profession; for companies, determined by objects and activities not personal qualifications

precedents.citation: William Esplen, Son and Swainston, Limited v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue 1 1919 2 K.B. 731

anchor.surface_text: William Esplen, Son and Swainston, Limited v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue  1 . In that case a private limited company was incorporated for carrying on business as naval architects and consulting engineers.

precedents.case_name: William Esplen Son and Swainston Ltd v Commissioners of Inland Revenue
precedents.cited_proposition: A limited company carrying on activities that would be a profession if done by individuals is instead carrying on trade or business because a profession depends on personal qualifications of an individual.
precedents.cited_holding: the company was not carrying on a profession but was carrying on a trade or business in the ordinary sense of the term

precedents.citation: Inderchand Hari Ram V. COMMissioner of Income-tax, U.P C.P. 1 1952 I.T.R. 108

anchor.surface_text: See Inderchand Hari Ram V. COMMissioner of Income-tax, U.P C.P. 1  . But when a company is incorporated it may not necessarily come into existence for the purpose of carrying on a business.

precedents.case_name: Inderchand Hari Ram v Commissioner of Income Tax UP CP
precedents.cited_proposition: A partnership firm carries on a business by definition under section 4 of the Indian Partnership Act.

precedents.citation: Commissioners of Inland Revenuev. The Korean Syndicate Limited 2 1921 12 Tax Cas. 181 at P. 202

anchor.surface_text: As was observed by Lord Sterndale, M.R., in Commissioners of Inland Revenuev. The Korean Syndicate Limited 2  If you once get the individual and the company spending exactly on the same basis, then there would be no difference between them at all.

precedents.case_name: Commissioners of Inland Revenue v The Korean Syndicate Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: In determining if a limited company is carrying on business, consider the particular purpose for which it comes into existence.
precedents.cited_holding: a limited company comes into existence for some particular purpose, and if it comes into existence for the particular purpose of concessions and turning them to account, then that is a matter to be considered when you come to decide whether doing that is carrying on a business or not

precedents.citation: Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. Birmingham Theatre Royal Estate Co., Limited 1 1923 I2 Tax Cas. 580 at P. 584

anchor.surface_text: Justice Rowlatt followed the above view of Lord Sterndale, M.R., in Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. Birmingham Theatre Royal Estate Co., Limited 1 , and held that when you are considering whether a certain form of enterprise is carrying on business or not, it is material to look and see whether it is a company that it doing it.

precedents.case_name: Commissioners of Inland Revenue v Birmingham Theatre Royal Estate Co Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: When considering whether a certain form of enterprise amounts to carrying on business, it is material whether a company is doing it.

anchor.surface_text: See Indian Law Reports 55 Calcutta 1059 and 1951 19 T.R. 571 . But they are relevant for the purpose of determining the nature and scope of such activities.

precedents.cited_proposition: The objects of an incorporated company as laid down in the Memorandum of Association are certainly not conclusive of the question whether the activities of the company amount to carrying on of business.

anchor.surface_text: See Indian Law Reports 55 Calcutta 1059 and 1951 19 T.R. 571 . But they are relevant for the purpose of determining the nature and scope of such activities.

precedents.cited_proposition: The objects of an incorporated company as laid down in the Memorandum of Association are certainly not conclusive of the question whether the activities of the company amount to carrying on of business.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the appellants are a partnership firm or a registered company the principle of exclusion of the income from the category of business income by reason of its depending wholly or mainly on the personal qualifications of the assessee would not apply because the income could not be said to be income from profession and neither a partnership firm nor a registered company as such could be said to be possessed of any personal qualifications in the matter of the acquisition of that income.

All these factors taken, into consideration alongwith the fixity of tenure, the nature of remuneration and the assignability of their rights, are sufficient to enable us to come to the conclusion that the activities of the appellants as the agents of the Company constituted a business and the remuneration which the appellants received from the Company under the terms of the Agency Agreement was income, profits or gain from business.
